title: 103_hr82
content: Restoration of deduction for interest on educational loans. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes defining personal interest to now include interest on qualified educational loans. This change restores the deduction for interest on educational loans. The definition of a qualified educational loan under section 163(h) of the Internal Revenue Code includes indebtedness provided through certain guarantee or insurance programs. A qualified educational loan is defined as any indebtedness provided through guarantee or insurance programs, organizations exempt from tax, or financial institutions under a supplemental education program. A qualified educational loan is incurred to pay qualified educational expenses within a reasonable period of time before or after the expenses are paid or incurred. A qualified educational loan is incurred to pay qualified educational expenses within a reasonable period of time before or after the expenses are paid or incurred. The amount of interest taken into account for the loan is subject to a phaseout of benefit. The amount of interest for a qualified educational loan is subject to a phaseout of benefit based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income for the taxable year. The taxable year's interest deduction is reduced based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income, subject to a phaseout range. For an unmarried individual, the applicable dollar amount is $40,000. For an unmarried individual, the applicable dollar amount is $40,000 with a phaseout range of $15,000. For a joint return, the applicable dollar amount is $60,000 with a phaseout range of $30,000. The applicable dollar amount for an unmarried individual is $40,000 with a phaseout range of $15,000, while for a joint return, the applicable dollar amount is $60,000 with a phaseout range of $30,000. The deduction is allowable only for the first 48 months when the loan is in repayment status. The deduction for student loan interest is only allowable for the first 48 months when the loan is in repayment status. The deduction for student loan interest applies to interest paid or incurred during the first 48 months of loan repayment for qualified educational expenses. The term 'qualified educational expenses' refers to qualified tuition and related expenses for attending an educational institution as defined in section 170(b)(1)(A)(ii). The term 'qualified tuition and related expenses' includes reasonable living expenses while away from home and may be adjusted for inflation in taxable years. The term 'qualified tuition and related expenses' includes reasonable living expenses while away from home and may be adjusted for inflation in taxable years. In the case of taxable years after 1994, the $40,000 and $60,000 amounts in subparagraph (B) will be increased for inflation. In 1994, the $40,000 and $60,000 amounts in subparagraph (B) will be increased by a cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. In 1994, the $40,000 and $60,000 amounts in subparagraph (B) will be adjusted for the calendar year by substituting 'calendar year 1993' for 'calendar year 1989'. Amounts not multiples of $50 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1993, for loans with the first required payment due after that date. Amounts adjusted under the rounding clause will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50.
